awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: PEEC Phase II: 2+2+2+Infinity: Pipeline for Tribal Preengineering to Society
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. The PEEC-II track provides support for studies or educational research conducted by institutions that have had earlier Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative (PEEC) awards.  The intent of PEEC-II is to capture, analyze, and disseminate the impact of these awards on the participating institutions, faculty, or students, and their communities. PEEC and PEEC-II are partnerships between TCUP and the Directorate for Engineering.

This collaboration among TCUP colleges Sitting Bull College (SBC), Cankdeska Cikana Community College (CCCC), Nueta Hidatsa Sahnish College (NHSC), and Turtle Mountain Community College (TMCC), and North Dakota State University (NDSU), is the culmination of more than 15 years of active engagement in STEM education on North Dakota reservations. It builds on the foundation of their PEEC award which created formal partnerships, implemented student support structures at NDSU, and developed means to support pre-engineering coursework at remote tribal college locations through distance learning and support of tribal college faculty.  The goals of this project are to 1) investigate and document the relationship between a new hybrid distance learning model applied to engineering education and its impact on recruitment, persistence and graduation of American Indian students, and 2) investigate and document the critical elements of the learning and support environments that can improve student success within engineering majors.

Along with creating sustainable and supportive pathways to engineering degrees for American Indian students, the broader impact of this project will come from the value of the distance learning model and its assessment, disseminated broadly, which can support STEM learning at the participating institutions as well as at other institution partnerships that are trying to improve pathways between rural or isolated schools and four-year institutions.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The most crucial activity of the project was a continuance of teaching activities at all 5 collaborative institutions. Every tribal institution had student participation in a local cohort and the mainstream institution were able to advance the cycle of transfer and graduation within its cohort. In each of the particular interest areas that follow, generalized descriptions of activities common to all collaborators were being followed by each of the collaborative institutions extending upon unique activities pivotal to the continuance of their programs. The following descriptions addressed the areas of recruitment, education, support, including supporting efforts for both student and instructor well-being and finally research activities.

Recruitment was critical to the sustainability of the program. Efforts were made to contact local high schools to make their students aware of the opportunities within the local pre-engineering programs. This was accomplished through visits to high schools, relationship building with high-school STEM teachers, and other forms of publicity (such as social media, newspapers, radio). In addition, each collaborating institution took steps to reach out to their own college students to evaluate available pre-engineering programs. Efforts were also made with helping with Sunday Academies. This was accomplished by helping and teaching Sunday Academy lessons, relationship building with high-school students that attended.  Another activity we did was having our AISES and Rocket team help put on a Science symposium at the middle/high school.

Another major activity was teaching courses that support the pre-engineering program. Each of the participant institutions continued offering courses to all participant institutions via the synchronous distance Interactive Video Network (IVN) technology utilized in the state of North Dakota, in accordance with the new hybrid distance learning model (NHDLM). During the life of the grant, in each semester 7 to 9 engineering courses, or engineering support courses were offered (typically Introduction to Engineering, Calculus I through IV, Linear Algebra, Engineering Mechanics and Dynamics). The local instructor at each site served as a mentor for students in all the courses offered as part of the program regardless of the instructor?s role or non-role in that course offering. The local instructors aided students in a mentoring and administrative capacity. We also had regular (typically monthly) in-person meetings of instructors and students from all participant sites, along with regular weekly meetings via conference calls. They resulted in a sharpening of the question and tools to be employed, and future collaboration should focus these elements into a research program that would allow for strong evidence-based practices and principles to be disseminated to parties of interest. As mentioned above, critical to sustainability of the program is recruitment of students onto the pathway of pre-engineering to engineering to professional employment. It is been the operative stance that each of the collaborating tribal college or university, TCU, be responsible for local recruitment because of their proximity and connections to that community.

One of our goals was to have at least five students be enrolled in the NHSC pre-engineering program in both Fall and Spring, as a way of focusing efforts and understanding related to the major activity of recruitment stated above. We exceeded the minimum of the objective most years but with Covid-19 the last few years our enrollment dropped below our goal. We have had 4 students total taking engineering instruction through Nueta Hidatsa Sahnish College (on site or via IVN) that have successfully completed their courses and graduated with their Pre-Engineering degree. From NHSC alone, two native students have completed their engineering bachelor?s degree. Program-wide there has been additional graduates receiving engineering bachelor?s degrees, with two obtaining their graduate degrees. 

NHSC is proud to have hired one of the PEEC graduates as an Engineering Faculty. That shows that PEEC I and PEEC II have gone full-circle showing we can now hire our own students that have successfully completed their degrees that required them to work at TCU's. 

 


Last Modified: 01/05/2022
Modified by: Lori Alfson
